frameDefinitions: Some Content is part of the mental model of a Cognizer.
An Experiencer has an emotion as caused by a Stimulus or concerning a Topic.
This frame concerns a Cognizer's certainty about the correctness of beliefs  or expectations.
A Cognizer has a piece of Content in their model of the world.
This frame contains words that necessarily indicate the motion of two distinct objects.
A Reported_fact is presented by the speaker as deriving from statements (made directly to them or to others) of third parties.
frameExamples: I fall asleep hours later to the sound of their <t>engrossed</t> murmuring.
Lermontov was <t>certain</t> he would come to the party.
Your boss is <t>aware</t> of your commitment.
She <t>accompanied</t> him in the ambulance to Hollywood Memorial Hospital.
Four <t>purported</t> gang members could face death penalty in Virginia slaying of federal informant.
listRoleDefinitions: The fact or idea which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is aware of.
The category whose applicability to the <fen>Content</fen> is known.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> has awareness (or lack thereof) of the <fen>Content</fen>.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The body part, gesture, or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The Time when the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is has a feeling about the <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose certainty or uncertainty is at issue.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the entity that a <fen>Cognizer</fen> has a certain/uncertain belief about.
The <fen>Content</fen> denotes the mental content that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is certain or uncertain about.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the mental state of  the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.

The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose awareness of phenomena is at question. With a target verb or adjective the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is generally expressed as an External Argument with the <fen>Content</fen> expressed as an Object or Complement.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s awareness. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a direct object or in a PP Complement.
Some verbs in this frame allow a <fen>Topic</fen> to be expressed in about-PPs.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part that reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state to the observer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is aware of the <fen>Content</fen>.
This is the entity, frequently a living being, which moves in relation to the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. Normally the <fen>Theme</fen> frame element is expressed as an external argument.
This frame element is the second moving object, expressed as a direct object or an oblique:

<fen>Source</fen> marks any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the motion of the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the  object expresses the starting point of motion. With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.

<fen>Path</fen> marks phrases that describe the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen>'s trajectory of motion and which are neither expressions of the  <fen>Source</fen> nor the <fen>Goal</fen> of motion. The notion <fen>Path</fen> also includes directional expressions.

Any expression which tells where the <fen>Cotheme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>. Note that if the <fen>Cotheme</fen> is animate, the <fen>Theme</fen> need not also end up in the same place. Some particles imply the existence of a <fen>Goal</fen> which is understood in the context of utterance.

<fen>Area</fen> marks expressions which describe a general area in which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.
Phrases that denote a physical path on which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place are marked <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> move.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location which provides a setting for a defined motion (that is one with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>).
An assertion of a state, event, property or existence or the assignment to a category that the speaker attributes to unnamed others.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Reported_fact</fen> was reported.
listRoleExamples: <fex>That most of them are dangerous</fex> is not yet known.
The patient arrived with a suspected <fex>broken leg</fex>.
The <fex>long</fex> suspected killer has now released a statement outlining his thoughts on the criminal case.
<fex>Marcel</fex> was sure that she had seen Eldridge on the balcony.
She talked of quests , of finding this absurd religious character , but he was unsure <fex>of her conviction</fex>.
I am sure <fex>that we'll arrive on time</fex>.
She caught sight of her mother's dubious <fex>expression</fex>.
<fex>Your boss</fex> is aware of your commitment.
Your boss is aware <fex>of your commitment</fex>.
Kim knows <fex>about first aid</fex>.
Bob's <fex>eyes</fex> were overly aware

Yet there is no evidence that Mr. Parrish was cognizant <fex>at the time of the signing
of the notes</fex> that the clauses in issue were present.
<fex>Pat</fex> accompanied me for five miles in a blue Toyota.
Pat accompanied <fex>me</fex> down the street.
The cat chased the mouse <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The bikers followed the truck <fex>west</fex>.
The children chased the ball <fex>into the park</fex>. (The children end up in the park.)
The police followed the suspects <fex>all around town</fex>.
The police followed the suspect <fex>on the interstate</fex> for several miles.
The tracking dogs chased their target <fex>towards the river</fex>, where they lost it.
Lester Hayes was purportedly <fex>joined in this suit by his wife</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The UK's Department for International Development (DfID)
the UK's Department for International Development
The UK's Department for International Development (DfID)
